content.protection:
Leading: Trad protection gear up to 3 inches.

TR: Could set up anchor for Top-Rope with a static rope or long slings from top anchor for Tootsie Pop route, wrapping it around horns as directionals.

Or perhaps could use sling  with directional from the My Sweet Tooth top anchor.
content.location:
Wide crack near Left side of East face.

--> See on

routes Photo SE

<--

... also on

routes photo East

...

content.description:
Easy climbing past two bolts. At the third bolt the angle steepens. Clip the bolt and make a funky type of mantle move to the anchors. This move isn't hard, just awkward.

A good first lead as it's well protected and while pulling the crux, the bolt is just below the waist.
content.location: On the south east side of the rock facing the parking area. The only bolted line on the rock.

content.description:
Lots of fun moves not difficult.

Up north (right) side of boulder to its top. Then up the NorthEast corner. Finish to the right of the corner.

Warning

: Rock is still breakable and loose, so belayer should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection:
Could set up anchor for Top-Rope with a static rope or long sling with directional from the two-bolt top anchor for My Sweet Tooth.

Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Boulder at foot of NorthEast corner (Right end of East face).

--> See on

routes photo East

<--

climbs.name: Starburst
climbs.fa: Ben Chapman, Pam Neal, Jeffrey Thomas, & Sandy Champagne (Nov. 2015)

content.description: Climb the right side of the face on amazing flakes and edges. Near the top move right to use friable flakes to then back left to the anchor.
content.location: Right side of the south face of Tootsie Pop Tower, left of Tootsie Pop.

content.description:
Up the crack, then finish up north side of fin onto top of the Tower.

Some thoughtful moves (? like "alpine" style ?) which are unlike most at Alabama Hills.

Warning

: Rock is still breakable and loose, so belayer should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection:
Could set up anchor for Top-Rope with a static rope or long slings through a hole near west end of one of the fins on top of the Tower.

Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
The Left-most crack on the West face. About two feet left from a thinner crack.

--> See on

routes Photo SW

<--

content.description: Begin climbing between the two seams opposite "Rock Candy" in the corridor. Pull on wonderful small positive edges and side pulls, on amazing bullet-proof monzonite. Continue straight up the face on great edges and jugs at the top.
content.protection: 4 bolts & anchor. Descend via the "Tootsie Pop" anchor, or scramble to the north.
content.location: East face of Tootsie Pop Tower. In the corridor between Tootsie Pop Tower and Rock Candy Tower, opposite "Rock Candy."

content.description:
Start on right side of thin crack. Up the right side of the crack to the top, using handholds to the left of the crack

Warning: Rock is still breakable and loose, so belayer should use caution.
content.protection:
Could set up anchor for Top-Rope with a static rope or long sling with directional from the two-bolt top anchor for My Sweet Tooth.

Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Thin crack near Right end of East face.

--> See on

routes photo East

<--

... also on

routes Photo SE

...

content.description:
Lots of thoughtful moves.

Without using the crack on the left or the crack to the right ... climb

Up the crack and finish onto one of the fins in top of the Tower.

Variation (easier): Place hands or feet on one of the adjacent cracks.

Warning

: Rock is still breakable and loose, so belayer should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection:
Could set up anchor for Top-Rope with a static rope or long slings through a hole near west end of one of the fins on top of the Tower.

Protection for Trad leading is unknown.
content.location:
Second crack from Left end of West face. About two feet right of a wider creek and four feet left of another narrower creek (Crack It Up).

--> See on

routes Photo SW

<--

content.description:
Up the crack.

Some thoughtful footwork is needed.

Warning

: Rock is still breakable and loose, so belayer should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection: A Top-Rope could be set up with a static rope or long slings on a horn and/or through a hole near the west end of the Tower.
content.location:
Wider crack near right end of West face. About four feet right from a narrower crack (Crack It Up).

--> See on

routes Photo SW

<--

content.description:
Fun moves on patina plates and features up the arete.

Warning: Rock is still breakable and loose, so belayer should beware.
content.protection:
Could set up anchor for Top-Rope with a static rope or long slings from top anchor for Tootsie Pop route, wrapping it around horns as directionals.

Protection for trad Leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
The arete between the South face and West face of the tower.

--> See on

<--

routes photo East

content.description:
Start just right of diagonal crack. Finish on top of the boulder.

Warning

: Rock is still breakable and loose, so belayer should stand far away from underneath the climber.
content.protection:
Could set up anchor for Top-Rope with a static rope or long slings through a hole near west end of one of the fins on top of the Tower. Needs a directional on the boulder.

Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Right-trending diagonal crack on West face of the attached boulder at the left end of the West face of the Tootsie Pop Tower.

--> See on

routes Photo SW

<--

content.description: Crux is just below the top. Fun crack climb. No jamming required, climbs like a face climb. Protects well.
content.protection: small stoppers, or cams to .75(BD). Need to build anchor with a #2, and #3 size cams.
content.location: the center of three cracks on the west face of Tootsie Pop Tower. Rap off the anchor that is used for the climb Tootsie Pop.

climbs.name: Butterfingers
climbs.fa: Ben Chapman, Pam Neal, Jeffrey Thomas, & Sandy Champagne (Nov. 2015)

content.description: Climb the left side of the south face of Tootsie Pop Tower on positive edges and flakes to a large hollow looking flake. With a right hand on the flake move up  to top out on good holds.
content.location: Left side of the south face.
